## Introduction

-   Angiosperms have an exceptional diversity of breeding systems
-   Simple associations are known e.g. selfing + short life span, dioecy + tree form
-   Can we use multi-trait approaches to identify more integrated reproductive strategies?

library(knitr)

tr<-read.csv(file = here::here("outputs/10_mfd_indices_wardD2_k3.csv"))
kable(tr) %>% kable_styling(font_size = 18)

## Diversity indices of clusters

::: panel-tabset
### Cluster 2

-   predominantly woody, dimorphic species
-   species are quite dissimilar within cluster (MPD, NND)
-   Species in cluster and distinct from other species in global pool (Fspe, Fori)

### Cluster 3

-   predominantly woody, monomorphic species
-   species are similar to each other within cluster (NND, MPD)
-   functional space filled by cluster is small (Fric)

### Cluster 1

-   predominantly herbaceous, monomorphic species
-   many species have extreme traits (near edge of cluster) (Fdiv)
:::

## Clustering similarities and differences

Strategies are broadly defined by two axes:

-   Woody vs herbaceous

-   Monomorphic vs dimorphic

Other traits like dispersal, mating system, symmetry split groups at finer scale but are not 'strategy defining'

-   these traits vary among clustering approaches
